so let's bump the .minor at least, i.e. 11.5.0 ... there are a lot of commits being picked up
https://github.com/openstack/puppet-tripleo/compare/11.4.0...stable/train

ironic/drivers/modules/redfish/managemen.message: Is this required? The task_uri is a Task URI and not TaskMonitor URI. Isn't it?
Done

Yes, this is required because as part of response we get only this "@odata.id': '/redfish/v1/TaskService/Tasks/17/" for task_uri. So to make it a complete Task URI, i did this change. 

To make it more clear 
TaskMonitor URI : https://172.17.1.108/redfish/v1/TaskService/TaskMonitors/17/

Task URI : https://172.17.1.93/redfish/v1/TaskService/Tasks/9/

it would be better to hide/abstract these differences in sushy, otherwise this will be necessary all the time when Redfish async operations are involved in Ironic (or any other sushy consumer) and I don't think that sushy consumers should think about these differences. In this scenario all it cares about is Task status/is it still running and messages.
Done

This update is changing the logic. Previous code was checking if `.message` field was populated (assuming that it will be populated not only for the first message, but also all the others). And if it is not populated then `parse_messages`. 

The current logic checks if there are any messages, and if there are, then parse. In this case the `.message` field might be already populated and will be overwritten. For iDRAC this field will be populated from BMC, by parsing&overwriting this could end up in worse message/might not have enough info to parse the message.

Is there a reason why this was changed? Something different in iLO? (mind the comment in ln 980-981 that is outdated by this change, if kept).
then could change this to `if sushy_task.messages and not sushy_task.messages[0].message` to keep the previous check also?

In case of iLO, sushy_task does not contain the messages attribute and because of that we were getting the below error.

AttributeError: 'Task' object has no attribute 'messages'

So provided the check if task contains the messages attribute or not.
Done
Please don't access private fields of sushy objects

> Please don't access private fields of sushy objects

Done
could go further and create a property in sushy that returns either task_uri or task_monitor - that is, this logic is part of sushy and does not need repeating in Ironic whenever Tasks are used.
Done

Done
if i understand correctly, you're specifically looking to add bgp - from the list of things that frrouting supports/provides right? might be good to be specific in this intro paragraph.
I added this clarification.
as noted in my last comment, might be good to mention that BGP is what you're specifically interested in (at this first stage perhaps) before this point.
Yes, good suggestion, I updated the doc to clarify this.
ah i see... so it is not just about BGP. Well, perhaps it is, i mean in this first pass you're looking to add bgp, so that we might also add these other things later. ?
In addition to the bgpd daemon, I believe other FRR daemons will also be needed such as watchfrr and bfdd.

I added text to mention BFD, but I didn't mention watchfrr or bfdd intentionally. I feel that watchfrr is an internal detail to FRR (it watches the daemons to make sure they are running IIUC). We need to validate that we will be using bfdd rather than an external daemon, but if
we settle on bfdd I may specify it more explicitly. Currently the bfdd daemon can be seen in the proposed changes, which I have linked to. Let me know if you disagree with my decisions and I will reconsider.
Can FRR run on a container? "packages are installed" specifies that it has to be installed on the overcloud image. Any specific reasons?

Yes frr can run in a container. Carlos and I got it working. We were kind of assuming that it had to be in a container given the general tripleo direction. Not sure if BGP (due to its low level nature) should be considered differently? I would guess not, but maybe there are other POVs about this?
Yes, I will clarify that the packages will be installed in the base OS but a sidecar container will be created to host the FRR daemons (Zebra, bgpd, and bfd daemons).

It is understood that FFR is going to run BGP daemon. Can it have additional details about the sources that we plan to configure to FRR? Are we planning to add a new source? It is also not clear about the routing information of what IPs, does it add routing info of all the overcloud IPs and VM IPs (local or fip or additional provider network)?

I have added links to the proposed upstream changes, as well as some description of the choices made for the default configuration in patchset #2, please comment on that version if you feel I need to add more.

would be good to consider/expand this a bit. as we discussed briefly at ptg it's going to be tripleo-heat-templates with parameters and then invoking tripleo-ansible role perhaps or whatever it is we can use to configure frrouter and friends on the nodes. ?
I expanded this section a bit, please have a look at the next revision and let me know if I should add more.
whitespace.
Will fix in the next revision, thanks.
Going the container way instead, FRR would be a THT deployment service so there are likely more work items to consider here.
I made this change and added links to the proposed changes including the container definition.
FRR is added as a container and there will be another sidecar container to FRR with required daemons?
FRR is added as a top-level container for HA, but in the case of Neutron data plane the FRR container would be a sidecar to the Neutron OVN service. I may need to clarify.
In case of DHCP managed by neutron/ovn, the information will be available. For external DHCP servers  (SR-IOV or OvS-DPDK provider networks), does OVN will have access to those IPs?

I am not sure if we can support BGP routing with external DHCP. The compute node would have to know which IP address(es) to advertise, so if the IP is in the OVN SB DB then I think it could work, but I'm not sure.

sqlite? Nothing in mariadb then? Wondering about the perf impact for a large(r) overcloud

Correct. we'll have to test the performance. If we can also fully implement the the spec for Scaling with the Ansible inventory[1], then that will help tremendously.

[1] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/tripleo-specs/specs/ussuri/scaling-with-ansible-inventory.html
can you be a bit more explicit here about the current limits i.e. a single threaded ephemeral heat can support up to X node deployments ?

I don't have the data yet, but I think it's clear it won't scale to today's requirements. We will have to explore making it multi-threaded/process and relying on the the Scaling with the Ansible Inventory[1] spec

[1] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/tripleo-specs/specs/ussuri/scaling-with-ansible-inventory.html
second time you mention it if there is a specific example please link it?
I don't have one. Alex mentioned it earlier, but we don't have a specific example (yet).
possible alternative, use Heat but make the stack itself ephemeral, for example dump DB and re-initialize heat prior to anything doing a stack operation.
I added that idea as an alternative.
To name a few, things like https://github.com/openstack/python-tripleoclient/blob/master/tripleoclient/utils.py#L1031 and missing network environment.
Thanks, that's a great example. I've added some points to the "overview" about how we can handle these types of scenarios.

An alternative would be to re-initialize the heat database on every run, and not use heat-all. We'd then keep the multi-threading capabilities that is there. But still benefit from not having all the issues with potential state in the heat stack.
I added the alternative of re-intializing the db to the "alternatives" section.

heat-all runs heat-engine and heat-api services in threads in a single process. Heat engine scalability is based around multiple workers in separate processes. When you specify a single worker, it's run in the parent process[1].

Also I don't think we can scale by using multiple heat-all processes in the undercloud (I'm sure it won't give the benefits of convergence heat engine).

To me it looks like (mentioned earlier too), if we want to converge standalone(undercloud) and overcloud deployments we've to change both.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.service/src/branch/master/oslo_service/service.py#L835-L839
Please consider making re-initialization the default for this proposal. With an optional "ephemeral mode". That would solve all scaling issues, f.e. when running upgrades.

Would these additional heat-engines be undercloud minions [1]? Are we planning to keep the minion feature for scale?

https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/tripleo-docs/latest/features/undercloud_minion.html
these would not be minions. I'm talking about the possibility of somehow running multiple heat-engine workers alongside heat-all, which today is not possible.

I think sqlite would not scale for overcloud stacks with large number of nodes.

AFAIK, sqlite requires too much memory to run if the database is big. It also has limitations for multi-thread access, connection sharing and some write performance.

Though I'm not saying we can't use sqlite for overcloud stack, we probably need to document this and see how it works.

If we go ahead with the option below, then we would not have these concerns.
second that, I know they tried to use sqlite for Metal3 and ran into issues with multi-thread access. I think they reverted to us a proper DB even tough it's "ephemeral".
I've listed this option in the "alternatives" section.
+1, I always like that idea.
Ack

would be nice to add some kind of estimated time frame to this..  more to signal that some of the things described here are beyond wallaby, even though you plan to start delivering some of these items during W.
Done
which templates are you referring to here? tripleo-heat-templates is already a repository so must be something else?
the templates used during the deployment, which are usually /home/stack/templates.

Have we thought about how to manage passwords and their rotations? Are we going to maintain a password file like undercloud (at present it's stored in plan or stack env)? We would atleast need to get them from the existing plan/stack before we move to ephemeral stack. I think it would not be simple to manage them outside of the heat stack with ansible (injecting into role data) after config-download.

only parts from the "tripleo deploy" code that I intend to use are the management of the heat-all process. I will probably refactor that out into tripleo-common as well. "overcloud deploy" will still work as it does today for all the plan management and environment management, then when it goes to actually talk to the heat api, it will start heat-all and use that api.

we could then migrate "tripleo deploy" to use "overcloud deploy", which is what I think we want to do anyway. That way, tripleo deploy has the benefit of things like password rotation, etc.

we can certainly revisit keeping the plan around. I view the plan as an intermediate step given it is deleted and recreated on every deployment. we do have a "plan deploy" command, but I'm not convinced any users rely on that functionality.

OK, I did not know that we want to continue using the overcloud plan (after tripleo-ui) which is in swift atm. If we still use the plan concept (local after swift removal) then we can't possibly use lot of tripleo deploy code other than using ephemeral heat.


I'm working on enabling server side heat env merging, which would require the plan to mostly dissapear.May be we'll address it with that effort.

yes, they're stored in the plan and that is where we can continue to retrieve them and manage them as needed. Using ephemeral heat shouldn't affect the plan usage at all, we still need the concept of the plan.

I think keeping the plan (as discussed above, containing passwords and derived parameters etc) is probably not aligned to statement earlier that "templates and environments passed to overcloud deploy would be the single source of truth". Probably we can clarify that here unless we leave it as a detail to be figured out later.

The scale testing is usually taken much later after the release, so this cannot be the predicate. Please consider adding that switch option from the beginning. And probably as the default deployment mode?
with the listed alternatives in the latest revision, we'd effectively have the same model we do today, so I do believe the scaling will be similar to the performance we offer today.
If we can do this we can avoid all the efforts around scaling heat-all and probably should prioritize this.
i plan to look at it

Given what it would take to finish that space, I've proposed something different in the latest patch set. Instead of using a single threaded heat-all, we can use separate ephemeral Heat processes which will allow us to start multiple engine workers. Management should be straightforward using a podman pod.

For sqlite, we can look at using MySQL. I'd still like to look at sqlite to see how bad of an issue we have with the performance.

Yes, I think this needs to be prioritized before implementing ephemeral Heat stacks. Please move that to the main proposal instead alternatives. Otherwise, scaling ephemeral heat-workers over sqlite would looks a waste effort to me.

sqlite has a major locking issue - meaning you can't really have a threaded process hitting an sqlite db... My take here is "avoid it", especially since we already have MySQL on the undercloud... If it's just a matter of ensuring the new ephemeral thing "creates the DB, fill it, output the data, dump the DB, drop the DB", I think it should be pretty easy/clean. Dumping the DB means we can investigate later by simply reloading it in some MySQL service.

octavia/db/migration/alembic_migrations/.message:
This one would be tricky..
I guess to make LEFT JOIN we need to switch to just 'join' here, as currently this migration got broken for MySQL

ERROR octavia-db-manage [01;35m[00msqlalchemy.exc.OperationalError: (pymysql.err.OperationalError) (1093, "You can't specify target table 'load_balancer' for update in FROM clause")
ERROR octavia-db-manage [01;35m[00m[SQL: UPDATE load_balancer SET flavor_id=%(flavor_id)s WHERE load_balancer.id IN (SELECT load_balancer.id 
ERROR octavia-db-manage [01;35m[00mFROM load_balancer LEFT OUTER JOIN flavor ON load_balancer.flavor_id = flavor.id

There were a couple of issues with this query:
- `is` and `is not` weren't properly translated to `__eq__` and `__ne__`, so those `WHERE` conditions never ended up in the compiled SQL statement; they were a result of trying to adhere to linting without double-checking the actual result
- since the `load_balancer` table is used in the joining subquery, it required relabeling the resulting column to avoid confusing the database engine
So, now we switched to using a constant -- this note should go away? Does this no longer trigger security tool errors? Which security tool was this in reference to?

This note was introduced as part of https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/octavia/+/692427/3..4 and build logs from that changeset are already gone.

My *guess*, based on my run-ins with Bandit in Openstack-Helm and Openstack-Helm-Infra recently, is that Michael may have wanted to use string parameterization in a raw SQL query, which under that assumption would flag that code as potentially SQLi-susceptible. Would like to hear from him, to be certain.

Delegating this responsibility to SQLAlchemy should effectively invalidate it, so I'll remove it for now.

groups.yaml.message:
The benefit I see about adding new groups is the granularity you provide, allowing you to catch different issues at different points. For example, in a pre-overcloud-update group makes the most of sense to check the templates format, roles_data syntax, etc...
The pre-update and post-update could be seen as generic health checks to see that we could start with the update or confirm that the update has succeeded. However, this enters in conflict with the groups pre-undercloud-update and post-overcloud-update. In my opinion they are the same:
pre-update = pre-undercloud-update and post-update = post-overcloud-update.

In the case of the upgrade, we left them present because they are part of the documentation for the FFU 13 to 16.1 procedure. So we can't get rid of them until the docs won't be updated. But the intention is to get rid of them and give a more granular set of checks. Something that you can run after each step that will provide you quick feedback if things are going well or if something is going to horribly fail if you continue that path.

That's what we need to discuss as I would like to hear voices of everyone. As for me, I would like to remove as it duplicates what we have in upgrade. However, there might be cases when pre-system-update may be different. As case I can tell RHEL 8 to RHEL8.1 upgrade so it might have own set of tests as we (upgrades) may focus on RHEL7 to RHEL8.X upgrades.

Thank Jose for the insight,

I agree, some (all ?) of the post-* have an equivalent (except for the post-update) in the following pre-*.  So +1 from me to get rid of them.

Now for the (pre|post)-system-update, I don't see their use neither so maybe we get rid of them as well.
Is there an "action"? Remove or keep? I don't understand the tradeoff(s) to keep or remove?

pre-update and post-update should stay, they definitively can be != than pre-upgrade and post-upgrade. Only xp will tell, if we end up with the same tasks here, then maybe we can refactor later.

Furthermore, until upgrade and update are "named" the same, I think we shouldn't confuse the user further.  Overall it's easy to share test in different group.
Is there an "action"? Remove or keep? I don't understand the tradeoff(s) to keep or remove?

I think the pre-system-update and post-system-update aren't really needed at this point in time. In the case of the upgrade, these groups are intended to run before a leapp upgrade (upgrade of RHEL from 7 to 8) and after it. The leapp upgrade has quite a lot of requirements and the pre-system-upgrade/post-system-upgrade allows us running a subset of validations to check that things are correct. But I don't think we will see a RHEL upgrade in the minor update (and if we do, we can always add the groups back)
I don't see immediate use of the *-system-update and the semantic difference with the other hooks. I would just remove them.

I would add a very important update step, namely "update run"

So we need to add "pre-update-run", "post-update-run".

pre-update: before updating the undercloud: check db size, check registration(?) + stuff from post-deployment?

pre-update-prepare: check undercloud updated correctly (container updated, undercloud image in the registry, template in good shape - whatever that means for that version), known issues warning (we know about them because tripleo-validation has been updated by now), ...

pre-update-run: verify that all images are present in the registry (if local), check registration for overcloud nodes, recheck db

pre-update-converge: check that all containers have been updated correctly, services running and in good shape, + stuff pre-deployment ?

post-update: maybe suff from post-deployement, and a nice message saying "you're wonderful"

So maybe that it all what is needed for a starter and we add more if we need them?

For the overcloud, as Sofer mention, you could have more granularity by providing groups before each step. The update (as well as the upgrade) is devided in:

-update-prepare (templates preparation)
-update-run (the update per se)
-update-converge (unsetting update parameters)

You could add a *-pre *-post group per each if it really makes sense for you, however it could also happen that there are no really significant validations to add in those intermediate points, if that's the case having only pre-update-run and post-update-run would be enough. Just think, are there interesting validations to run between those steps? For example a check of the templates preparation couldn't run if you have only one stage. As when you will kick off your pre-overcloud-update-run group validations the update prepare step hasn't run yet.

tripleo_ansible/roles/backup_and_restore.message: why do we want to suppress all errors for all the commands?
I have been thinking and the ignore errors in this block is only derived to the fact that the previous command can have errors. I have fixed this replacing it with a var check in patch set 10

Because they could fail because a varied number of reasons: firewalld is not installed, the playbook is being run in Debian/Ubuntu and a plethora of different conditions that can happen in a variety of different distros and configurations.

I think it is cleaner to just suppress the errors and continue with the playbook. If this two commands fail, we can say that it was not necessary to open the ports at all.
We shouldn't be using firewalld at all?

But the NFS server to store the backups can be any server. Ports are opened with iptables directly in the previous step, but if firewalld is running it closes the ports ignoring iptables config.

So either we open the ports, disable firewalld or leave it as an operator's problem (he need to open the ports manually or disable firewalld in the NFS server or the backup will fail). What is better?
eh ok. we're really not consistent on this
We configure iptables directly and don't use firewalld as part of openstack
Why? It comes preinstalled in rhel and it is not better to open ports instead of plainly disabling it from the NFS server?

controllerconfig/controllerconfig/contro.message:
is this required even if the role is not systemcontroller ?
also, these appear to be currently populated on a lab with deployed subclouds - should dc_keystone_password and local_keystone_password exist on the subcloud?

> As we talked, this password is subcloud's local dcmanager user's password. Since dcmanager is a system controller only service, dcmanager is not configured, not active on subcloud (and non-DC system). So the dcmanager user along with its password should not present in non-system-controller. But as John points out, we currently sync dcmanager user/password in dcorch. That probably should be removed as well.

However, if cert-mon running on system controller is using this user to access subcloud APIs (thus need to authenticate against subcloud's keystone), then this user along with its password has to exist in subcloud keystone. Since dcorch sync this user, it would have the same password as the dcmanager user in system controller. The locally generated password would be obsolete.

The dcmanager user is mandatory in the subclouds. The dcmanager/dcorch in the system controller use this user to authenticate with services in each subcloud. See https://opendev.org/starlingx/distcloud/commit/d10fef48217d69a45084dd8b81c30d3bbe68b3af for details.

As we talked, this password is subcloud's local dcmanager user's password. Since dcmanager is a system controller only service, dcmanager is not configured, not active on subcloud (and non-DC system). So the dcmanager user along with its password should not present in non-system-controller. But as John points out, we currently sync dcmanager user/password in dcorch. That probably should be removed as well.
Yes, the cert-mon is extended to monitor and renew other certificate, e.g platform certificates, which is not limited on DC system.
The dcmanager is one of the synced centralized user and it needs to be stored in the subcloud keystone. However, it does not need to be stored in the secure_static.yaml on subclouds.

please add a comment to that effect as the current hieradata and variable names allude to dc (i.e. dc_keystone_password).  Also, it appears dc_pass will be nil for non systemcontroller (whereas appear to observe a value set in a lab deployed subcloud).
this password (dc_keystone_password) is only for DC cert-mon. it is used to access subcloud API. As in the code, it is only assigned a value when the it is a systemcontroller.
Sorry just saw Bart's comment after I sent out my last comment.

tobiko/openstack/neutron/_client.py.message:
This function should get the floating_network_id from from below stack in the case it is None:
  
 create_floating_ip(floating_network_id=None, client=None, **params):
   if floating_network_id is None:
     from tobiko.openstack import stacks
     floating_network_id = tobiko.setup_fixture(
       stacks.FloatingNetworkStackFixture.external_id)
   if floating_network_id is not None:
     params['floating_network_id'] = floating_network_id

This the REST APIs to create a FIP:

https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/network/v2/index.html?expanded=create-floating-ip-detail#create-floating-ip

I would prefer to pass parameters like below:

 def create_floating_ip(floating_network_id: str, client=None, **params)
   params['floating_network_id'] = floating_network_id
   floating_ip = neutron_client(client).create_floatingip(
     body={'floatingip': params})

In this way we make it the function more pythonic by separate required parameter from optional ones. Please note the API only accept a dictionary containing an entry with a 'floatingip' key, so we can just skip asking for repeating such structure every time we call our create_port function.

This is the API used here:

https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/network/v2/index.html?expanded=update-floating-ip-detail#update-floating-ip

The API requires a dictionary with a constant 'floatingip' key, so we can just skip asking for repeating such structure every time we call our update_cloating_ip function. This implementation should be OK:

 def update_floatingip(floating_ip: str, **params):
   floating_ip = neutron_client(client).update_floatingip(
     floating_ip, body={'floatingip': params})
   return floating_ip['floatingip']

I think we should use neutron functions instead of directly using the client here. The reason is we do need to abstract neutron API so that we can replace the client if we want (please think about switching to neutron CLI or OpenStack SDK instead of python clients in case it makes sense).
Agree. Done

We should implement a neutron.create_port and neutron.create_port and neutron.delete_port functions. Please have a look at neutron.create_network and neutron.delete_port as examples. Just after calling neutron.create_port we should call self.addCleanup:

  port = neutron.create_port(network=self.stack.network_id)
  self.addCleanup(neutron.delete_port, port['id'])
Agree. Done

We should create neutron.create_floating_ip and neutron.delete_floating_ip functions as mentioned above regarding neutron.create_port and neutron.delete_port functions. Please note cleanup functions has to be registered in the same order resources are creates, so that cleanups are called in the reverse order.
Agree. Done

Instead of deleting things in tearDown you should register a cleanup function for every single resource so that if the deletion of a resource fails the deletion of the other is still attempted. Cleanups has to be registered as soon a resource is created so that cleanups are called in opposite order of creation.

Example:

  port = neutron.create_port(name=self.id())
  self.addCleanup(self.delete_port, port['id'])
  floating_ip = self.create_floating_ip(name=self.id())
  self.addCleanup(self.delete_floating_ip, floating_ip['id'])

Above code at the end of the test case will call:

  self.delete_floating_ip(port_id['id'])
  self.delete_port(floating_ip['id'])

The difference is that an individual call is being registered for every single resource, and any failure will not cause not trying to delete other resources.

Anyway I do prefer using heat template so that we can manage these resources more comfortably.

In case anyone else is looking at this, I resolved it by using a specific postgres Enum, as discussed in the commit message of the next PS [1]

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/758396/7//COMMIT_MSG#62

This in sync with the 271 migration. However I feel this also have the potential to introduce conflict in postgres and sqlite. Obviously it does not cause any problem right now or we would have a fat bugreport open. So meh.

that is a compound fix for multiple things. This index was missing in sqlite and fixed in 273. Also it was special cased before for mysql and for postgres, that is now replaced with a common index definition. It looks good.
as far as I see this is a remainder for the mysql specific indexes from L1109 the rest was moved to be engine agnostic index. Looks good
